ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture and in-person lab.
In-person studio space, not required but encouraged to use, reconfigured for social distancing.
Live studio course meetings on zoom
virtual crits with the professor and TAs, in person desks available.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I made a significant transition from working primarily in drawings to working through models, which I struggled with in my previous studios

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I felt like the surrogate project went on longer than was productive. However, I did not feel fully warmed up and ready to tackle the final/primary project after just the surrogate project. I think the course would have benefitted from having a third assignment sandwiched between the surrogate and the library project. 

As for the library project, having a clearer brief (and continually re-centering on that brief) would have been helpful. The talk about program and how that merges with form would have been very helpful to have towards the beginning of the project as opposed to after mid-review. I also had trouble wrapping my head around the projectwe focused a lot on the programs provided by a library but then we weren't tasked to alter the library. I also had trouble with the idea of disrupting the entire street in front of the library. 

Despite these points, I still think it was a great studio. Annie always had really inspiring and fruitful content and given the weird virtual studio during COVID times, this was probably the best that a studio could have gone.

I think this course ended up functioning shockingly well on zoom. I think we could've used a little more guidance in the first half of the semester as we began to engage with our projects, but other than that this course ran smoothly. Using canvas would have been helpful too.
lots of one on one time with the professor was good. could used a little bit more structure in how the class was organized.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Architecture studio is infinitely better with access to our work desks, workstation computers, and fabrication machinery in the building. Having access to Rudolph was extremely helpful and conducive to better studio work.
I thought the zoom portion of this class ran as well as it could have.
Having access to the workspace made this course almost like before the pandemic, I am extremely glad the school organized access for us
virtual crits with the professor and TAs worked well. did not think it was necessary to make a real model.
I love not having to print all my projects, but sometimes it was difficult to have all the images be somewhat the same size

I actually loved having to put together presentations virtually instead of in-person pin ups because then by the end of the semester, everything was already documented and edited nicely. Also no printing costs!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only for students in the architecture design major.

You have to take it for the major, but would recommend it to others if I could. Annie is wonderful and going to class most days just felt like I was catching up with my friends and having a good time :)
